title: Strong U.S. Recovery Aids Growth in Canada, Mexico
summary: Central bank officials in both Mexico and Canada have raised their forecasts for economic growth in their respective countries, in part because of the strong U.S. rebound.

summary: Antitrust lesson 101: Big government often makes big business bigger.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Purdue Builds Support For Bankruptcy Deal; Tobacco Co-Op Squares Off With Farmers; Junk Bond Rally Intensifies
summary: Purdue Pharma’s family owners brought holdout states on board with their settlement offer, boosting the company’s efforts to cede itself to the public. The biggest tobacco cooperative in the country detailed its long fight with its farmers. And investors’ enthusiasm for risky debt hit a new milestone.

title: ECB Alters Policy Framework; Makeup of Regional Fed Boards Criticized
summary: The European Central Bank is changing its policy framework for the first time in nearly two decades. It said it would aim to keep eurozone inflation at 2% over the medium term, instead of the current target of just below 2%, and would allow room to overshoot its target when needed. In the U.S., regional Federal Reserve Bank boards don’t reflect the country as a whole, though most directors are supposed to represent the public, according to a report from a left-leaning advocacy group.

title: Fixing Climate Change Isn’t the Central Bank’s Job
summary: The ECB joins the fight against climate change, but there are problems posed by mixing environmental mandates with financial regulation enforced by unaccountable institutions.

title: American Frackers Show Restraint as Oil Tops $70
summary: Shale companies pumped with abandon anytime oil prices rose sharply last decade. But as crude tops $70 a barrel, they are barely doing enough to sustain U.S. production.

title: Stocks Skid on Economic Worries
summary: The Dow shed about 260 points and Treasury yields extended their decline as investors unwound bets on a period of high growth and inflation.

title: It Looks Like a 19th-Century Cottage. But This English Home Is So Much More.
summary: Louise and Francis Shardlow used the remains of an old parchment-making factory in their backyard to extend the house and give it a more contemporary look.

title: ECB Aims for Slightly Higher Inflation, Stops Short of Fed’s Major Shift
summary: European Central Bank officials forged an agreement to aim for slightly higher inflation, but stopped short of the major policy shift unveiled in 2020 by the Federal Reserve.

title: Why Rising Oil Prices Are Unlikely to Kill the Economic Recovery
summary: The recent rise in oil prices has been mostly driven by increased demand rather than supply problems, a situation that economists say normally indicates resilient growth.

title: Global Wind, Solar Capacity Rose at Sharpest Pace Ever Last Year, BP Says
summary: Growth in renewables saw global solar-power capacity rise around 22%, while wind-power capacity rose around 18% compared with the previous year, BP said in its annual review of global energy markets.

title: Fed Weighs Earlier Stimulus Pullback; U.S. Employers Clamoring for Workers
summary: The Federal Reserve’s June policy meeting minutes released Wednesday offered a strong sign that officials will ramp up deliberations over reducing their bond buying when they next meet July 27-28. The minutes showed how officials have been surprised by a stronger-than-expected surge in price pressures as the economy reopens. Meanwhile, the number of U.S. job openings held at record levels headed into the summer as employers sought to fill positions from a limited pool of workers. The Labor Department is set to report the latest unemployment-claims figures at 8:30 a.m. ET.

title: Riverside Co.’s Kohl Reflects on Navigating Private Equity’s Market Resurgence

title: Higher Oil Prices Can Only Help Shell So Much
summary: Supermajors have traditionally used their heft to ride out price volatility, paying steady dividends through the cycle on the secure assumption of rising demand over the long run. As the world transitions to cleaner energy sources, that growth is no longer a certainty, giving the likes of Shell a much more challenging balancing act.

title: Fed Minutes in Focus; Bitcoin Fraud Concerns Draw Scrutiny From Regulators
summary: The Federal Reserve’s minutes from its June meeting, due out at 2 p.m. ET, will be scrutinized by investors for any discussions among policy makers about when they may ease back on bond-buying programs. Following the June meeting, officials signaled they expect to raise interest rates by late 2023 and discussed an eventual tapering of their asset purchases, giving a jolt to markets. Meanwhile, financial regulators are signaling they want more control over an expanded cryptocurrency universe that has pushed further into Wall Street activities without the investor and consumer protections that apply to traditional securities and financial services.

title: Texas Teacher’s Neil Randall Says He’s Unfazed by High Valuations

summary: The President wants the cartel to pump more oil, but the U.S. to pump less.

summary: Stocks were down after the long holiday weekend, with the Dow industrials leading the market lower with a 0.6% decline.

title: Lower-Wage Workers Benefit From Easing Pandemic; RBA Says QE Tapering to Start From September

Australia’s central bank said it would taper its quantitative easing program in September, despite a fresh wave of pandemic-related lockdowns over recent weeks. And U.S. job-openings figures are the highlight of the week’s slate of economic data.

title: Philadelphia Fed’s Harker Wants Bond Buying Taper to Start; Regional Fed Banks, Senator Squabble Over Climate, Social Justice Work
summary: Count Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia President Patrick Harker among the Fed officials who think it would be a good idea for the U.S. central bank to start paring its $120 billion a month in bond buying stimulus. “I would like to see tapering begin,” he told The Wall Street Journal in an interview. “I’d like to see it happen sooner rather than later.” Meanwhile, Sen. Patrick Toomey (R., Pa.) says the Atlanta, Boston, Minneapolis and San Francisco Fed banks are ignoring his requests for information about their work on racial economic justice and climate issues, in a dispute highlighting the limits of congressional oversight over the regional institutions.

title: PE Daily: LLR Bets on Video Software | Siguler Guff Banks $450 Million | EIG Begins Limetree Bay Restructuring Talks
summary: Exits are piling up as more sponsored companies plan IPOs or blank-check deals with the same end in mind. More than a dozen IPOs were expected this week, and we have details below on several that have either been registered or completed, including two notching double-digit first-day trading gains. The threat of higher capital gains taxes is one of the forces driving the flurry of deals, PricewaterhouseCoopers says.

title: Fed’s Bostic Expects Rate Increase Next Year; Bank of Korea May Raise Rates This Year
summary: Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic has revised his forecast for an interest rate increase by the Fed from 2023 to late 2022, citing a stronger economic recovery than he had expected earlier in the year. The new forecast makes Mr. Bostic, a voting member of the Federal Open Market Committee this year, one of a small but growing number of Fed officials who expect to raise rates next year. He also said the time is coming soon for the Fed to pare its $120 billion a month in bond buying stimulus. Outside the U.S., the Czech Republic’s central bank raised rates, while South Korea central-bank chief said a rate rise is on the cards.

title: Broader Stock Indexes Slip as Nasdaq Hits Record
summary: U.S. stocks held on to most of their gains from earlier in the week as the S&P hovered just shy of its all-time high.

title: PE Daily: Banner Ridge Tops Target | Lincolnshire Recap Dissected | Blue Owl Sees Path to Success
summary: Home prices jumped last month to record levels around the U.S. amid a shortage of properties for sale and would-be buyers armed with low-rate loans. Stepping into that picture is Blackstone with its latest multi-billion dollar housing purchase which no doubt will inflame critics who see private-equity investments in residential real estate as a reason why many Americans are unable to afford a home of their own. Never mind the difficulties many would-be buyers encounter in trying to save enough for a down payment, or the blemishes in credit records that can bar access to low-rate loans. Blackstone and other investment firms see single-family rentals as an attractive business in the current market, as our Journal colleague Peter Grant reports.

title: OPEC Alliance Considers Boosting Production Amid Uneven Recovery
summary: The Saudi-led organization and its allies are considering boosting the group’s collective output by some 500,000 barrels a day when they meet next week, delegates said, representing a modest boost to the world’s supply of crude.

summary: The race to secure electricity deals for power-hungry data centers has tech companies reshaping the renewable-energy market and grappling with a new challenge: how to ensure their investments actually reduce emissions.

title: The Green Hydrogen Puzzle Is Starting to Fall Into Place
summary: Replacing fossil fuels with green hydrogen in the economy is a bit like doing a jigsaw puzzle: Once a few early pieces are connected, it will be much easier to fit the others. A plan from one of the world’s top wind-turbine makers can help.
